definition-item.definition-title: PRINTING, DUPLICATING, MARKING, OR COPYING PROCESSES; COLOUR PRINTING, (correction of typographical errors B41J; processes for applying transfer pictures or the like B44C1/16; fluid media for correction of typographical errors by coating C09D10/00; printing textiles D06P)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Non-digital and digital printing processes in general, wherein an image or pattern is created on a substrate surface.

section-body.paragraph-text: This place does not cover:
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

definition-item.definition-title: Inking and printing with a printer's forme

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Non-digital printing methods, i.e. "conventional" printing methods.
Only methods that are purely printing methods.

section-body.paragraph-text: The subgroups relating to different printing methods (e.g. intaglio printing, B41M1/10) maybe used in combination with the subgroups relating to security printing, B41M3/14.

definition-item.definition-title: Printing on other surfaces than ordinary paper (B41M1/40 takes precedence)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

Non-digital printing methods, i.e. "conventional" printing methods, used for printing on other surfaces than orfinary paper, including: metals, organic plastics, horn or similar materials, rubber, glass or ceramic surfaces, wooden surfaces, leather or linoleum.
In this place, the following terms or expressions are used with the meaning indicated:

table-column.paragraph-text: sheets made of traditional paper mass

definition-item.definition-title: Printing processes to produce particular kinds of printed work, e.g. patterns ({printing apparatus or machines of special type or for particular purposes B41F17/00;} special designs or pictures per se B44F; manufacturing printed circuits using printing techniques H05K3/12 {; manufacturing organic semiconductor devices using printing techniques H10K71/13})

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Digital or non-digital printing processes.
This place does not cover:

table-column.paragraph-text: Rapid manufacturing and prototyping of 3D objects by additive depositing

definition-item.definition-title: {Colour cards; Painting supports; Latent or hidden images, e.g. for games; Time delayed images}

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Postcards; Greeting, menu, business or like cards; Letter cards or letter-sheets with peel-away layer hiding information
Designs or pictures characterised by special or unusual light effects

definition-item.definition-title: {Patterns of chemical products used for a specific purpose, e.g. pesticides, perfumes, adhesive patterns; use of microencapsulated material; Printing on smoking articles}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
E.g. printing adhesive patterns, printing silver ink patterns.

definition-item.definition-title: Transfer pictures or the like, e.g. decalcomanias {(processes for producing decorative surface effects B44C1/00; B41M5/0256 takes precedence)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods of making (printing) the picture to be transferred.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Processes for applying transfer pictures or the like
Processes for decalcomanias; sheet material therefor

definition-item.definition-title: Security printing {(securities B42D25/29)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods which concern the security printing process.
The subgroups relating to different printing methods (e.g. intaglio printing, B41M1/10) maybe used in combination with the subgroups relating to security printing, B41M3/14.
This place does not cover:
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Preventing copies being made of an original by using an original which is not reproducible or only reproducible with a different appearence

definition-item.definition-title: {Transitory images, i.e. images only visible from certain viewing angles}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
E.g. images printed with differently reflecting pigments.

definition-item.definition-title: Particular kinds of wallpapers

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods for printing on wallpapers.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Flexible structures being applied by the user, e.g. wallpaper

definition-item.definition-title: Duplicating or marking methods; Sheet materials for use therein (by using light-sensitive materials G03; electrography, magnetography G03G {; repeatedly usable boards or tablets for writing or drawing B43L1/00})

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Printing methods for printing on different kind of surfaces.
Digital printing, i.e. not using printer's forme.

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Materials or methods for recording or reproduction by optical means (DVDs, CDs)

definition-item.definition-title: {Digital printing methods characterised by the inks used (inks per se C09D11/00)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods where the ink is used in a special way, e.g. two per se known inks are used in combination giving a special effect.

definition-item.definition-title: {Uncoated paper (paper making D21)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods for printing characterised by the ink receiving properties of the paper without a separate ink receiving layer.

definition-item.definition-title: {Digital printing on surfaces other than ordinary paper (B41M5/0082 takes precedence; printing on textiles D06P5/00)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

Digital printing methods, i.e. not using printer's forme, used for printing on other surfaces than orfinary paper, including: metals and oxidated metal surfaces, plastics, horn, rubber, other organic polymers, glass, ceramic, tiles, concrete, stones, wooden surfaces, leather, linoleum, skin or flowers.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Deposition of organic semiconductor materials on a substrate by ink-jet printing

section-body.paragraph-text: In the subgroup B41M5/0041 and in its hierarchical lower subgroups it is highly desirable to add, if applicable, complementary classification in B41M5/0082 or in its hierarchical lower subgroups.
For example, if the invention is about an ink-jet printing method on a wooden surface, both classes B41M5/0047 and B41M5/0076 should be given.
However, if the invention is about an ink-jet printing method on a wooden surface having a particular shape (e.g. curved surface), the following classes should be given: B41M5/0088 and B41M5/0076.
In this place, the following terms or expressions are used with the meaning indicated:

table-column.paragraph-text: sheets made of traditional paper mass

definition-item.definition-title: {Digital printing on bodies of particular shapes (sublimation or volatilisation of pre-printed design B41M5/035)}

section-body.paragraph-text: In the subgroup B41M5/0082 and in its hierarchical lower subgroups it is highly desirable to add, if applicable, complementary classification in B41M5/0041 or in its hierarchical lower subgroups.
For example, if the invention is about an ink-jet printing method on a wooden surface, both classes B41M5/0047 and B41M5/0076 should be given.
However, if the invention is about an ink-jet printing method on a wooden surface having a particular shape (e.g. curved surface), the following classes should be given: B41M5/0088 and B41M5/0076.

definition-item.definition-title: by transferring ink from the master sheet

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Transfer printing with intermediate carrier.
The principle of transfer printing is as follows:
the image transfers by melting: B41M2205/06
the image transfer by sublimation: B41M2205/02
B41M5/025 (melting image)
B41M5/035 (sublimating image)
B41M5/0256 (melting + sublimating image)

definition-item.definition-title: {the transferable ink pattern being obtained by means of a computer driven printer, e.g. an ink jet or laser printer, or by electrographic means}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
E.g. transfer pictures for T-shirts are quite often printed with this kind of method.
In this place, the following terms or expressions are used with the meaning indicated:

table-column.paragraph-text: printers for digital printing methods, i.e. methods not using printer's form

definition-item.definition-title: by sublimation or volatilisation of {pre-printed} design {, e.g. sublistatic (B41M5/0256 takes precedence; printing on textiles D06P5/00)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Methods wherein the already printed design is transferred using heat on a substrate.
Only the design i.e. the ink is transferred and not the whole layer. The designs may be produced by the methods classified in B41M5/0256.

section-body.paragraph-text: This place does not cover:

definition-item.definition-title: {characterised by the mechanisms or artifacts to obtain the transfer, e.g. the heating means, the pressure means or the transport means}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

Printing methods where the transfer of the ink from the master sheet is made by sublimation or volatilisation of desing and wherein the method is characterised by specific details of the mechanisms to obtain the transfer, e.g. the heating means, the pressure means or the transport means.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

definition-item.definition-title: using pressure to make a masked colour visible, e.g. to make a coloured support visible, to create an opaque or transparent pattern, or to form colour by uniting colour-forming components

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Pressure sensitive papers.

definition-item.definition-title: Ablative recording, e.g. by burning marks; Spark recording {(marking by high energetic means, e.g. by laser otherwise than burning or ablative removal B41M5/26; materials or methods for recording or reproduction by optical means G11B7/00)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods wherein the material is removed from the surface (only ablation imaging).
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Working by laser beam, e.g. welding, cutting, boring
Processes for producing decorative surface effects by removing surface-material with laser radiation

definition-item.definition-title: Thermography (B41M5/20, B41M5/24 take precedence); {Marking by high energetic means, e.g. laser otherwise than by burning, and characterised by the material used (B23K takes precedence; thermographic or photothermographic systems using noble metal compounds G03C1/494)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Methods wherein the material changes colour, when marked (without ablation).
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

definition-item.definition-title: {recording or marking of inorganic surfaces or materials, e.g. glass, metal, or ceramics (marking of plastic artifacts with inorganic additives B41M5/267)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Thermographic recording or marking methods of inorganic surfaces or materials, including: glass, metal or ceramics. The recording or marking is usually made by an infrared laser.
Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

definition-item.definition-title: using thermochromic compounds or layers containing liquid crystals, microcapsules, bleachable dyes or heat- decomposable compounds, e.g. gas- liberating {(B41M5/38271 takes precedence)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Characteristic for these methods is that there is no chemical reaction, i.e. the colour change takes place within one compound or by destroying said compound.

definition-item.definition-title: using chemical colour formers (B41M5/34 takes precedence)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Thermography without transfer, i.e. thermo-sensitive recording, direct thermal recording.
There is chemical reaction between two or more compounds, which results in colour change.

section-body.paragraph-text: The following table shows the relevant classification places for different layers of direct thermal recording sheets:

table-column.paragraph-text: B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups

section-body.paragraph-text: *An Indexing Code (a hierarchical lower subgroup of B41M2205/00) is given to specify the printing method and layer (e.g. direct thermal printing, intermediate layer, back layer, etc.).

definition-item.definition-title: Colour developing components therefor, e.g. acidic compounds

section-body.paragraph-text: In this place, the following terms or expressions are used with the meaning indicated:

table-column.paragraph-text: anything that reacts with the colour formers

definition-item.definition-title: {Sulfur compounds, e.g. sulfones, sulfides, sulfonamides}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Sulphur compounds having phenolic or carboxylic acid groups.

definition-item.definition-title: using a polymeric layer, which may be particulate and which is deformed or structurally changed with modification of its' properties, e.g. of its' optical hydrophobic-hydrophilic, solubility or permeability properties {(B41C1/10 takes precedence)}

section-body.paragraph-text: For lithographic printing plates normally only class in B41C1/10 is given. However, a class is given in subgroup B41M5/36 or in its hierarchical lower subgroups, when lithography is not mentioned in the independent claims.

definition-item.definition-title: Contact thermal transfer or sublimation processes (sublistatic printing using a pre-formed image B41M5/035; ink-, dye- or pigment-receptive coatings B41M5/52)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Only the donor layers for imagewise heating.
The donor layers of the thermal transfer ribbons are classified in this subgroup and its hierarchical lower subgroups.

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Deposition of organic semiconductor materials on a substrate using non liquid printing techniques, e.g. thermal transfer printing from a donor sheet

section-body.paragraph-text: The following table shows the relevant classification places for different layers of thermal transfer donor sheets:

table-column.paragraph-text: B41M5/382 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups

section-body.paragraph-text: *An Indexing Code (a hierarchical lower subgroup of B41M2205/00) is given to specify the printing method and layer (e.g. melt transfer, d2t2, intermediate layer, back layer, etc.).
The principles of melt transfer and sublimation transfer are as follows:
melt transfer:
B41M5/382 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
+ B41M2205/06 (for melt transfer)
sublimation transfer:
B41M5/382 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
+ B41M2205/02 (for sublimation transfer)

definition-item.definition-title: {Anthraquinone or naphthoquinone dyes}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

definition-item.definition-title: {Dyes containing one or more acyclic carbon-to-carbon double bonds, e.g., di- or tri-cyanovinyl, methine}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

definition-item.definition-title: {Dyes characterised by an acyclic -X=C group, where X can represent both nitrogen and a substituted carbon atom}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

definition-item.definition-title: Dyes containing one or more carbon-to-nitrogen double bonds, e.g. azomethine

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

definition-item.definition-title: characterised by the base {backcoat}, intermediate, or covering layers, {e.g. for thermal transfer dye-donor or dye-receiver sheets}; Heat, radiation filtering or absorbing means or layers; combined with other image registration layers or compositions; Special originals for reproduction by thermography {(macromolecular ink- or dye-receptive coatings B41M5/52)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

The layer structures of both direct thermal recording and thermal transfer sheets (= thermal transfer donor sheets and thermal transfer receiving sheets) except the image receiving layer of the thermal transfer receiving sheets (see the table below).
Classification for thermal transfer receiving sheets:

table-column.paragraph-text: B41M5/52 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups
B41M5/42 and its hierarchical lower subgroups

section-body.paragraph-text: *An Indexing Code (a hierarchical lower subgroup of B41M2205/00) is given to specify the printing method and layer (e.g. direct thermal printing, intermediate layer, back layer, etc.).

definition-item.definition-title: characterised by the light-to-heat converting means; characterised by the heat or radiation filtering or absorbing means or layers

section-body.paragraph-text: An Indexing Code (a hierarchical lower subgroup of B41M2205/00) shall be used to show which layer is in question, e.g. intermediate layer, cover layer or back layer.

definition-item.definition-title: Recording sheets characterised by the coating used to improve ink, dye or pigment receptivity, e.g. for ink-jet or thermal dye transfer recording {(printing on organic plastics using a printer's form B41M1/30; printing on pre-treated paper with a printer's form B41M1/36)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

The subgroup B41M5/50 and its hierarchical lower subgroups cover also recording sheets for non-digital printing methods (i.e. methods classified in group B41M1/00 and its hierarchical lower subgroups).
The following table shows the relevant classification places for different layers of all but thermal recording sheets:

table-column.paragraph-text: B41M5/52 and its hierarchical lower subgroups

section-body.paragraph-text: *An Indexing Code (a hierarchical lower subgroup of B41M2205/00) is given to specify the layer (e.g. intermediate layer, back layer, etc.).
In the following the principle of transfer printing when the whole layer with the printed image is transferred is shown:
for the method: B41M2205/10
for the receiver: B41M5/50 and/or B41M5/52 and their hierarchical lower subgroups
for the protective layer: B41M7/0027, B41M7/0036, B41M7/0045 or B41M7/0054

definition-item.definition-title: {characterised by structural details, e.g. multilayer materials (supports, backcoats or intermediate layers for thermal dye transfer donor and receiver sheets B41M5/41, B41M5/42)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Intermediate, support, and backcoat layers for non-thermal receiving elements.
Particular shapes in receiving sheets, e.g. perforations, missing corners.

definition-item.definition-title: Macromolecular coatings

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Ink, dye or pigment receiving coatings/layers for recording sheets.

definition-item.definition-title: After-treatment of prints, e.g. heating, irradiating, {setting of the ink, protection of the printed stock (pre-treatment or treatment during printing B41M5/0011; printers for treating or overcoating copy materials before, during or after printing B41J11/0015)}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:

list-item.paragraph-text: Any kind of after-treatment of previously printed material, also protective coatings.
After-treatment of both digitally and non-digitally (by conventional printing methods) printed products.

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

definition-item.definition-title: {Obliterating the printed matter; Non-destructive removal of the ink pattern, e.g. for repetitive use of the support}

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
E.g. methods relating to mechanical removing of the ink.

definition-item.definition-title: {using ink-fixing material, e.g. mordant, precipitating agent, after printing, e.g. by ink-jet printing, coating or spraying}

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: Application of ink-fixing material on the substrate prior to printing

definition-item.definition-title: Processes wherein make-ready devices are used (make-ready devices per se B41N6/00)

section-body.paragraph-text: This place covers:
Printing methods wherein make-ready devices are used. Typical methods using said devices are disclosed e.g. in documents US1730229, US2825282 and US2587439.

definition-item.definition-title: Cover layers; Layers separated from substrate by imaging layer; Protective layers; Layers applied before imaging

section-body.paragraph-text: Attention is drawn to the following places, which may be of interest for search:

table-column.paragraph-text: After-treatment of prints, e.g. heating, irradiating
